texts.definition: Algorithms created to provide what appears to be intentional behavior.
markups: <style="Definition">Algorithms created to provide what appears to be intentional behavior.</style>

Many games worlds contains more entities such as animals, people, monsters, or robots that have behaviors that are not decided by players. To make this possible these entities are instead have more or less complex rules, algorithms, that decide which actions they should take. The simplest only contain a couple of rules taking not consideration to what the other players or entities have done while the most complex have processes for learning under which contexts one should perform what actions.

Already most of the earliest computer games, including <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Nim">Nimatron</link></style>, OXO (a computerized version of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tic-Tac-Toe">Tic-Tac-Toe</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asteroids">Asteroids</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Invaders">Space Invaders</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bomberman%20series">Bomberman series</link></style> made use of algorithms to control opponents to the players. It is still used in many games, e.g. in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed%20series">Assassin's Creed</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/God%20of%20War%20series">God of War</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Need%20for%20Speed%20series">Need for Speed</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization</link></style> series. In some of these cases (i.e. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tic-Tac-Toe">Tic-Tac-Toe</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Need%20for%20Speed%20series">Need for Speed</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization</link></style>, and, somewhat paradoxically, multiplayer versions of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake</link></style>), the <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> replaces human opponents while in other cases being part of the game world. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> uses <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> not only for the infected that attack the players' characters, but also to control other player characters if there are not four people available. In all these case the <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> are also used to provide opponents but in games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fable%20II">Fable II</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style> the <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> also control animals that accompany the players' characters.

<style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> are also used to provide a basis of behaviors to agents in a game which players can then modify, as for example in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Lemmings%20series">Lemmings</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style>, or indirectly control, of which the  <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Black%20&%20White%20series">Black & White series</link></style> is an example. Games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/RoboRally">RoboRally</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style>, where players have to choose several actions together before they are enacted, can also be seen as examples of games that use <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> even if players create the algorithms/instructions and the outcomes are fixed unless some external factor is changed (e.g. the position of the other robots in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/RoboRally">RoboRally</link></style>. MUDs<ref name="MUDs"/> typically give experienced players privileges to modify the game environment, and for those supporting more generic coding such as LPMUDs<ref name="LPMUDs"/> this can be in the form of independent entities capable of initiative and adaptive responses. In contrast, programming games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crobots">Crobots</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/P-Robots">P-Robots</link></style> challenge players to create better algorithms than other players before gameplay begins.

The use of <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> by necessity require game designer to consider what <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> should exist in the game and what algorithms control their behavior. Which algorithms to use is not only a question of creating them, but also considering who can create them. The most common case is that they are created in advance by game designers but another possibility is to allow players to create the algorithms. The simplest form of this is <style="Link"><link="action-programming">Action Programming</link></style> (as for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/RoboRally">RoboRally</link></style>) and can be seen more as command sets in that they do not take input from the environment while being executed. Examples of games supporting actual coding include both pure programming games, such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crobots">Crobots</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/P-Robots">P-Robots</link></style>, as well as MUDs, which use it to provide user-created content.

The types of <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> available depends primarily on how they relate to players and their goals. <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> have <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style> compare to the players' goals and are typically <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> but <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> can also be used to control <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, thereby creating <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> as long as they at least seem to have their <style="Link"><link="own-agenda">Own Agendas</link></style>. The latter can also be used to create <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> so <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> can be created with players (examples include various humans characters in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> and animals in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fable%20II">Fable II</link></style>), either through having <style="Link"><link="mutual-goals">Mutual Goals</link></style> or having individual <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals"> Continuous</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> in relation to the players' goals. <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> may both be <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> but these may also have their <style="Link"><link="own-agenda">Own Agendas</link></style> independent of player goals. <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> may of course also change what role they have during gameplay, either due to <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> which may in turn cause <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> or as effects of players' actions through use of the pattern <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>. One example of this can be found in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>, where players' <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> may abandon or attack players who start behaving differently than when they started to cooperate. What constitutes relevant behavior for all these types of <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> depend on what ambitions for <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> exist.

However, players may not perceived <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> as <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> if their behavior is too predictable<ref name="Lankoski2007"/> even if the entities diegetically convey that relation and behavior. Instead, players may reduce them to <style="Link"><link="converters">Converters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="containers">Containers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="self-service-kiosks">Self-Service Kiosks</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>. Although this may be impossible to hinder if players achieve <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> or simply play long enough, there are many ways to make this take longer time. <style="Link"><link="initiative">Initiative</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="context-dependent-reactions">Context Dependent Reactions</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="contextualized-conversational-responses">Contextualized Conversational Responses</link></style> can all make the <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> function more in relation to the current context in their <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, while <style="Link"><link="awareness-surroundings">Awareness of Surroundings</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style> forces players to consider what the <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> can sense. <style="Link"><link="memory-important-events">Memory of Important Events</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="own-agenda">Own Agenda</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sense-self">Sense of Self</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="goal-driven-personal-development">Goal-Driven Personal Development</link></style> all show ways of how to prolong the time until the <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> are no longer seen as <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> (often this include an application of <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style> in comparison to other similar <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>). Since it is algorithms that create these behaviors, <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> both instantiate these patterns and are affected by them.

For games aiming at <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style> can also be required since otherwise overarching patterns for the <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> may be found and their apparent agency might lessen. Both these may be created through the use of giving the <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> the ability to have <style="Link"><link="goal-driven-personal-development">Goal-Driven Personal Development</link></style>. Many of these solutions require the development of AI systems and require extensive testing to ensure their functionality is what is intended. A complementary approach to this creating <style="Link"><link="unpredictable-behavior">Unpredictable Behavior</link></style> through the use of <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> or significantly complex rules controlling the behavior. <style="Link"><link="ambiguous-responses">Ambiguous Responses</link></style> can also be used to make the illusion of intentionality last longer since players have more possibilities to read intentionality into the actions (an approach made famously by the computer program <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/ELIZA">ELIZA</link></style><ref name="ELIZA"/>).

A less common use of Algorithmic Agents is to interweave it with a player's control of an Avatar or Character. Some games, e.g. the Super Mario series and Fable II, use them when players' have not provided input for extended periods of time to indicate diegetically that the Avatar or Character is becoming bored but return control to the players as soon as input is provided. Other games, e.g. the Lego Star Wars series and the Left 4 Dead series, have them as backup AI Players that can step in when Game Pauses are desired, and by doing so enable Drop-In/Drop-Out gameplay. Concurrent shared control between human players and Algorithmic Agents has been discussed in research for affecting the behavior Characters in general, and exists in FPS games through aimbots

<style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> do not themselves exist in a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> but since they are typically tied closely to specific <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, it is necessary to consider both how the <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> should be able to observe what happens in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> and how they can act in it.

In <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style> focused upon creating <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> it is necessary to include interfaces for this, often including functionality to ensure that the algorithms are properly expressed and the possibility to test them. In games with <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> controlled by <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> it may be necessary to provide specific interface components so that players can modifying their behavior, something which exist for example in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> are necessary if players are to be able to interact with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> that exist in <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>, and in this case it is important that they maintain the game's <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> if one aims at evoking an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> to the unfolding storyline. Providing <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style> to <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> allow them to show <style="Link"><link="emotional-attachment">Emotional Attachment</link></style> to what happens in the game world.

Since they do need to be designed, <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> are <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> if any type of narration is taking place in a game.

<style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> are powerful tools that can make sure a game includes <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style>, since game designer can create them with <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style> to the players' goals and be sure that these will be acted upon (which is not always the case when given to players). However, <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> can just as well used to support <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>. Regardless, the <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> can provide both <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> and this may be incorporated into <style="Link"><link="handicap-systems">Handicap Systems</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style>. A side effect of this is that the <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> can be used to modulate how much <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> a game requires, and how difficult this is. Regardless, since most <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> in games interact with the game through actions in a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> is a very common component when designing <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>.

Since <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> can be used to create <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style>, it makes it possible to make <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> and thereby providing players with a way to have a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curve</link></style> at the expense of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style>. Another effect of this is to allow <style="Link"><link="game-pauses">Game Pauses</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> gameplay styles in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. Of course, <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> can be turned into <style="Link"><link="zero-player-games">Zero-Player Games</link></style> by the same approach, although this is typically only done for supporting <style="Link"><link="no-direct-player-influence">No Direct Player Influence</link></style> through letting players of a <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Game</link></style> create the <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style>. When the use of <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> are temporary, i.e. they replace players for limited periods of time, this provides support for <style="Link"><link="interruptibility">Interruptibility</link></style>.

When made by the game designers or developers, <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> provides <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style> and can offer ways of achieving <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> on more general levels of a game. Their behaviors may however take time to understand and until this is achieved they may instead give <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Planning%20Ability">Limited Planning Ability</link></style>. In contrast, player-generated algorithms offers players some <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> and may be used to support <style="Link"><link="mules">Mules</link></style>. This also typically encourages <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style> since creating the algorithms requires an understanding of the game system regardless of a specific game state. Even if the <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> typically are abstract construction, they might be considered in this case be viewed as <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>, especially when the creation is linked to <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> that would otherwise not be present in the game. When the creation of the algorithms are part of the set-up phase, <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> can create <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style> where the inner game has <style="Link"><link="no-direct-player-influence">No Direct Player Influence</link></style> and might work against players having an <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>. This allows programming games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crobots">Crobots</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/P-Robots">P-Robots</link></style> to let players have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Indirect%20Conflicts">Indirect Conflicts</link></style> with each other in the sense that they try to create <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> that are in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> with each other (due to <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style>) but that these players themselves do not perform confrontational actions. When possible during gameplay, the creation of <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> by players is an example of <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style> and player-controlled <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style>.

The combination of players and <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> influencing the actions of the same <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> can lead to a conflict over the amount of agency players have, and for this case the pattern can work against <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empowerment">Empowerment</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>.

While <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> often are realized through code running on computers and thereby set a bound on <style="Link"><link="ubiquitous-gameplay">Ubiquitous Gameplay</link></style> to require computers, this is not always the case. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Power%20Grid">Power Grid</link></style> have expansion with <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> contained on <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="interruptibility">Interruptibility</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Planning%20Ability">Limited Planning Ability</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="memory-important-events">Memory of Important Events</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="mules">Mules</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="no-direct-player-influence">No Direct Player Influence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="own-agenda">Own Agenda</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sense-self">Sense of Self</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ambiguous-responses">Ambiguous Responses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="awareness-surroundings">Awareness of Surroundings</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="contextualized-conversational-responses">Contextualized Conversational Responses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="context-dependent-reactions">Context Dependent Reactions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="goal-driven-personal-development">Goal-Driven Personal Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="handicap-systems">Handicap Systems</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="initiative">Initiative</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="memory-important-events">Memory of Important Events</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="own-agenda">Own Agenda</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sense-self">Sense of Self</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="unpredictable-behavior">Unpredictable Behavior</link></style>

Stopping to consider <style="CurrentLink">Algorithmic Agents</style> as <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> may cause the removal of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>
